instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00923: What is 820-00923? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Power button not working.
threads.message: This board had a spill around the power button. I cleaned it up and all the pins on the power button connector are functional and reading correct diode numbers compared to a good board. Touch ID works fine. The power button is pulling <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> low and I'm measuring that all the way over to <RESISTOR>R5170</RESISTOR>, but the computer is not responding. I've checked all the resistors on the line. Everything looks good. The spill was very minimal. <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is measuring 3.4V. Nothing wrong with anything in the circuit that I can find. Is this just the SMC not responding? Not sure what else it could be.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Power button not working.
threads.message: Do you mean the machine turns on, but cannot turn off with power button?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Power button not working.
threads.message: Yes, everything works normally but the power button has no effect, it doesn't turn it on or off, even though it's pulling <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> low.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Power button not working.
threads.message:
Machine still stays on if pressing power button more than 5s?
Just in case, test with <RESISTOR>R5225</RESISTOR>/26 pads, instead of power button.
Check continuity between different points of <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>; may have a broken trace.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Power button not working.
threads.message:
Yes, it stays on. Pressing the power button has no effect no matter how long I hold it. It doesn't turn it on or off.

No change when using pads. Continuity is good between all the points. <SIGNAL>SMC_OFF_L</SIGNAL> is measuring about .715 in diode mode so that's normal also.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Power button not working.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Power button not working.
threads.message:
Disconnect touchID and try with <RESISTOR>R5225</RESISTOR>/26 pads.
In fact, disconnect anything from the board.
It will turn on automatically, when charger is connected; just test if you can turn it off.
